div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE GROWTH OF ORIENTAL NATIONALISM.
div.p: The new spirit in the East and the growth of Nationalism in Asia are the subjects of an article of quite extraordinary interest in that modest quarterly "The East and the West" for October. The special article we quote here is written by the Rev. C. F. Andrews, of Delhi.

"Two years ago," he says, "I ventured to write an article in this review on the effect of Japanese victories upon India and the East. In certain directions I may claim to have made a true forecast. There has been a distinct un-

div.head: P & O WEEKLY MAIL and PASSENGER SERVICES P & O

settement in Mohammedan lands and a growing restlessness under European domination; there has been also in India itself an increasing movement towards the iberalising of Islam, without apparently say nearer approach to Christianity; and on the Hindu side there has been a remarkable revival of reforming Hinduism, especially among the members of the Arya Samah in the North; lastly, there has been a still more remarkable development of nationalism, of which I stated the opinion that, "it is still a tender plant, but when it is grown it may cover the land,"...

"The one dominant factor, resulting from the Japanese war, has been the growth of the spirit of nationality and the desire among the enlightened in all Eastern lands for national progress. This spirit has literally pssed from one end of Asia to the other, and is strong in Egypt. While taking colour from the religion of each country it is primarily a political and racial movement, though at the same time I believe it to be full of religious import. There is a striking similarity in the forms of the new thought and the new literature that is being produced. I have seen newspaper extracts from Teheran, Cairo, and Pekin, and the subjects discussed are almost identical with the leading articles of the "Bengalee" or the "Hindu." They may be roughly summarised as a desire for Western institutions and scientific training, national aspiration, and a race longing for freedom from European control. SOmetimes race feeling predominates, sometimes the passion for Western culture, sometimes the simple desire for national progress.

From one point of view the Renaissance in Europe is the nearest parallel to what is now taking place in Asia; for, as Bishop Creighton has pointed out, along with the breaking up of old systems and the intellectual impulse of that age, there came an awakening of the nations to self-consciousness and the formation of Modern Europe on national lines.

"The breaking up of old systems of thought and government has begun in every part of Asia. An Indian friend has told me only to-day that he has just finished reading twelve different Persian newspapers and reviews, and the chief subjects of discussion in each were 'Parliamentary Government,' 'Persia for the Persians,' 'National Progress,' and such like. The visit of the Amir of Afghanistan to India has been followed by the inauguration in Kabul of a system of elementary and advanced education on Western lines. In Pekin a Parliamentary constitution has been promised, scientific and technical institutions have been erected, nearly 20,000 students have gone to Japan for training, and Western education has already taken the place of the old classics in the Civil Service examinations.

"India has developed the Swadeshi movement; from one Bengal society alone 100 students were sent abroad this year for technical instruction; in every college and in every newspaper 'nationalism' is the one subject of interest and discussion; in many parts a racial antipathy against the foreigner has grown up, which has called for the sternest measures of repression. The growth of nationalism in Egypt formed the principal theme of Lord Cromer's farewell address in Cairo.

"These events, and instances might be multiplied, are no passing phase. They are the beginnings of a movement which will extend in mightier and mightier circles among the myriads of the unlettered peoples. To take India as an example, the village peasants in the North to-day are discussing political questions which were only known to be educated two years ago. What has been told in the ear is being proclaimed upon the housetop. It may be that there will be reactions and eddyings in the current; but the great tide which has started from Japan will sweep away all temporary barriers, and we shall witness in our own generation the awakening of half the population of the world.

"The breaking up, then, of the East has begun, the awakening is already in progress. With very much of this Renaissance- with the longing for freedom and enlightenment, the desire for a true and healthy national existence the wish to elevate the countless myirads of the common people- no thoughtful Christian can fail to sympathise. The progress of the East may check his sense of race superiority, and bring most difficult questions as to government and control, but as a Christian first, and an Englishman afterwards, he cannot but rejoice. For in all that is happening he can recognise the transplanting of Christian thought in Eastern soil.

div.head: Mena House.
div.p: Mena House hotel will re-open for the season next Sunday.

div.head: The Zarkat Murder.
div.p: The police have arrested four men on the charge of murdering the omdeh of Zarkat.

div.head: The "Mahroussa."
div.p: The Khedivial yacht "Mahroussa" has taken a short trip out to sea in order to test her engines, which have been undergoing repairs.

div.head: Mansourah Municipality.
div.p: The receipts of the Mansourah Municipality during the financial year just ended were L.E. 29,000 against an expenditure of L.E. 22,000.

div.head: Abbassiah Barracks.
div.p: The war office have appointed a board of officers under the presidency of Colonel Herbert Bey, to study the plans of the new barracks to be built at Abbassia.

div.head: Another Provincial Murder.
div.p: The body of Osman Abdeen, nazer of Messrs. Bustros and Khelat's esbeh at El Ettchad, has been found in the Bahr Hafeer. The police have come to the conclusion that the man was murdered and several arrests have been made.

div.head: Guarde Draft for Egypt.
div.p: The next outgoing colonial military relief transport (the "Sicilia," leaving Southampton on October 31) is to take out the reinforcing draft from the Coldstream Guards for the 3rd Batt. of the regiment in Egypt. Sec. Lieut. Viscount Feilding will go out with the reinforcement.

div.head: Alexandria Criminal Court.
div.p: The criminal court of Alexandria has sentenced Ali and Ghali Hagag to 10 and 17 years' imprisonment with hard labour for the theft of camels in the Behera province and for having fired upon the commandant of police. Shakat who was tried on the same charge was acquitted.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe via Port Said and Brindisi will be made up at the G.P.O Alexandria, at 3.15 p.m. on Sunday 20th for ordinary correspondence, 2.15 p.m. for registered correspondence, midday for money orders and insured articles and at 6 p.m. on Saturday 19th for parcels.

div.head: Postage Abroad.
div.p: In accordance with the decision of the last Postal Congress, all postal administrations of the Union will from the 1st to 28th November next compile statistics of the weights of correspondence sent abroad. As these weights cannot be taken until the last moment the administration finds it necessary to advance, by the half an hour, for the said 28 days, the closure of the outward mail. Correspondence posted after times indicated must of necessity await the next mail, and during this period mail steamers will not receive letters sent on board for despatch. It should also be noted that letters for abroad cannot, during this time, be posted on the mail trains.

The leading article in the "Times" on the subject of General Ahmed Dhellaleddin Pasha's letter has evoked the following comment from Mr. Halil Halid who writes-"During the 12 years and more I have resided in England, I have never read anything in the English Press so impartial and so just about the nearer East as the leading article you published on Friday last under the heading "The Turks and Their Rulers." It is a good sign of the times for the people of Turkey that you should review Turkish affairs in so reasonable a light at a time when a growing activity is perceptible in many quarters to improve the condition of the Ottoman Empire.... Now, Sir, in your leading article, you assure us the goodwill of the English people towards Turkey. We should all welcome that goodwill and the re-establishment of the influence of the Government of this country in Turkey, not, as I must emphasize, as a fault-finding dictator, but as a friendly Power. Permit me to say, however, that your warning is rather disturbing to the Turks, when you say that England cannot give active support to the political aspirations of the Turkish people, although you assure us that they might look forward to her support in the promotion of the economic improvement of the country. If even two Turks cannot come together to promote a business enterprise, and if every legitimate combination, financial or industrial, is regarded as a conspiracy against the person of the present Sultan, no efforts for economic improvement could be of any avail. What we should expect from official or unofficial Englishment interested in the affairs of Turkey is not so much active support under the existing condition of our country, but only some help in the work of spreading the pacific reform propaganda all over Turkey, which has hitherto been ruthlessly hampered by the authorities of the Hamidian autocracy."

div.head: WALKER AND MEIMARACHI.
MEETING IN LONDON.
div.p: London, Friday.

A lengthy meeting of the shareholders of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi Ltd. was largely attended yesterday afternoon. On Maltre Carton de Wiart objecting to Mr. Drower as chairman, the meeting elected Mr. W. T. Western to the chair. After a long discussion, in which Nungovich Bey spoke strongly in favour of the Cairo board, the following resolutions were passed unanimously:
(1) That it was desirable to adjust the differences between the London and Cairo boards as quickly as possible:
(2) That it was desirable to again secure the services of Mr. Meimarachi as general manager with a seat on the board;
(3) That until after the next ordinary general meeting no casual vacancy should be filled by the directors except by appointment of persons approved at this meeting;
(4) That Mr. Meimarachi be approved accordingly.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL COMPANY.
SIR W. GARSTIN APPOINTED DIRECTOR.
div.p: London, Friday.
Sir William Garstin has been nominated to fill the late Major General Sir John Ardagh's place as director of the Suez Canal Company.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive visited Ramleh this morning and attended midday prayers at the mosque of Abou Bishr. His Highness was accompanied by Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria.
On Monday evening next his Highness will entertain the leading Moslem merchants of Alexandria to "iftar" at Ras el Tin palace.

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS.
THE COAL CONTRACT.
div.p: The Egyptian State Railways has adjudicated on the tenders for the supply of 240,000 tons of Cardiff coal. The tender of Messrs. Pyman Watson and Company, for 110,000 tons, of Messrs. William Milburn and Company, for 65,000 tons, and of Messrs. H.C. Vivian and Company, for 65,000 tons, have been accepted. All these firms belong to Cardiff.
The Egyptian State Railways has stipulated with the successful firms tendering that the coal supplied shall be from those classes of coal, which are on the British Admiralty List.

div.head: THE MIXED COURTS.
A BLOCK OF BUSINESS.
div.p: At to-morrow's sittings of the Mixed Civil Court at Alexandria no less than 450 cases are down for hearing. Judge Prumeres will preside.
During this week in one sitting of the Cairo Mixed Civil Court 2300 new cases were down for hearing.

"Al Mokattam" states that no less than three hundred and eighty "protets" were handed in on Wednesday last at the Cairo Mixed Courts. The staff at the Tribunals were extraordinarily embarrassed owing to the unwanted amount of business.

div.head: ANIMALS FOR THE ZOO.
div.p: Captain Stanley Flower, Director of the Zoological Gardens returned to Gizeh yesterday from Roseires (Blue Nile) bringing with him a valuable collection of Sudanese animals, including five lions, a waterbuck, tiang, hartebeest, oribi, duiker, leopard, monkeys, ostriches, whistling teal, crocidiles, chameleons, etc.

div.head: GRAND CONTINENTAL HOTEL.

div.p: Will be open during Winter

div.head: THE MODERATE PARTY.
div.p: Hafiz Awad, one of the chiefs of the Egyptian Moderate Nationalist Party, has determined to appeal to the French Consulate at Cairo against the criticism of M. Colrat, the French journalist, and has lodged a complaint asking that proceedings should be taken against that gentleman for the alleged violent nature of his articles against the Moderates.

div.head: KAMEL'S VISIT.
div.p: Musapha Pasha Kamel hopes to receive a great welcome at Alexandria when he comes to make his speech at the Zizinia Theatre. Yesterday the town was flooded with free invitations to the Pasha's discouse. The Zizinia Theatre has been hired for the evening at the cost of £80. Kamel's partisans are trying t organise a reception for him on the arrival of his train, but his envoys complain that there is little enthusiasm in Egypt's commercial capital.
The following am using paragraph appears in the "Egyptian Standard" of yesterday:-
In our issue of yesterday through an error in the translation, by Mr. Rudy, a mistake slipped into the text which we desire to rectify.
The French text ran as follows:
"Il y montrera la grandeur du parti national, le but poursuivi par lui, la necessite pour tons les Egyptiens de se grouper autour de lui, comme le seul qui represente vraiment la nation."
The passage was translated as follows:
"He will speak about the greatness of the National Party, the goal he has in view, the necessity for all Egyptians to be grouped around him as the only man who represented the Egyptian nation."

It is clear from the French text that him should have been "it," and the only man who the "only party which." The text would then read: ""He will speak about the greatness of the National Party, the goal he has in view, the necessity for all Egyptians to be grouped around it as the only party which represents the nation."

It is needless to say that the foundation of the National Movement is a principle and not any man. Leaders may die but the movement will continue. Our Director is merely the servant of this great principle old so invites Egyptians to follow it.

div.head: THE PARTY OF THE PEOPLE.
div.p: The recent formation of the "Party of the People" continues to give rise too vast amount of discussion in the columns of the vernacular Moslem Press. "Al Guerida," the organ of this political group, states that a number of Government officials are to be found in its ranks, but that they cannot taken an active part in the organisation of the party because of their employment.

"Al Moayad," in an article in its issue of Wednesday, declares that the programme of the party of the nation has been filched from that of the moderate nationalist party and that it does not contain any original item. The organ of Sheikh Any Youssef is very upset at the foundation of this new party, which it accuses of insincerity.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MARKETS DIVIDEND.
div.p: The improvement which we foreshadowed some weeks ago in the dividend to be declared by the Egyptian Markets takes the form of an interim distribution for the first half-year of 1907 at the rate of 7 per cent, as against 6 per cent, at this time last year. This is in itself a most satisfactory result. But it must be remembered that the company's operations have only quite lately been extended by the important addition to them of the agency for the sale of salt, so that the current half-year should show an increase of profit much more considerable than that which is reported for the first six months. It cannot be too often repeated that the monetary nad speculative crisis which has caused so much trouble in Egypt, and has sadly depreciated the securities in which speculation was most rife, has had hardly any effect upon the business of this undertaking ("Daily Report").

div.head: MILITARY NOTES.
div.p: Lieut.-Col. J. F. Donegan, R.A.M.C., has left Cairo for Khartoum and the charge of the military hospital, Cairo, has been assumed by Major J. C. Jameson, R.A.M.C.
Kaimakam Lloyd Bey has been appointed acting O.C. Kordofan district.
Major W.P.G. Mylres, A.S.C., has returned from leave, and resumed his membership of the Army of Occupation remount committee.
Brevet Major H.A. Porter, D.S.O., Liverpool Regiment, has been selected for service with the Egyptian Army.
Captain Reginald F.M. Sims, D.S.O., has resigned his commission in the King's Royal Rifle Corps.
Mirali Bond Bey, D.S.O. director of steamers and boats, Sudan Government, has arrived in Cairo.
Capt. M.J. Hamilton, Lancshire Fusiliers, returning to England from service with the Egyptian Army, has been attached to the 2nd Batt. of his regiment in Ireland.
hon. Lieut. T.H. Dimiek, Inspector of Army Schools, is now in Cairo, having completed his inspection of the Alexandria school.
Supernumerary Lieutenant Athelstan Moor, D.S.O., Royal Dublin Fusiliers, has been promoted Lieutenant, vice W.H. Whyte, placed on temporary half-pay on account of ill-health.

div.head: ANTI-CLERICALISM AT ALEXANDRIA.
A SCHOOL TABLET.
div.p: The anniversary of the birth of Haribaldi has led to an unfortunate misunderstanding between the members of the Italian Colony of Alexandria and the Italian Minister for Foreign Affairs, Signor Tittoni. On the day in questions the members of the committee, selected to organise the festivities, decided to set up a marble tablet with the following inscription in the Italian Government School in Abou Dardaa street:-

I pronipoti della generazione che vide nascere - il 4 luglio 1807-Giuseppe Guribaldi- apprendan in queste acule-che daila morte del dogma- hanno vila la scienza e la morale- dinani alle quali-tutte le confessioni-cadono.-La Colonia Italiana-4 luglio 1907.
The English version is as follows:-

The offspring of the genration which say the 4th July, 1807, birthday of Giuseppe Garibaldi, will learn in these schools that through the death of dogma science and morality take their birth, whereby all religions fall to pieces.
The Italian Colony.

Three days before the date the tablet was shown to the Marquis di Soragna, the Italian Consul at Alexandria. He raised an objection to the wording as it was nsuited to a school, which was neither religious nor anti-clerical in its tendencies. The committee wherein six masonic lodges were represented, paid no attention to the criticism of the Marquis and put up the tablet. The Marquis refused to stop during the ceremony of putting the tablet in position and left the school. The Foreign Office at Rome were informed of these proceedings and on the 23rd ulto. Signor Pianeitini, the acting-consul, received orders from the Minister for Foreign Affairs to have the tablet taken down forthwith. This was at once obeyed. When the members of the Radical section of the Italian Colony got wind of this, they were sent off to Rome. The Italian chamber of Deputies then took part in the squabble and the Anti-Clerical political groups at Rome asked the Government why the tablet had been officially removed and whether such tactics were not a surrender to the Vatican. The excitement among the colony were increase and now the Italian Radicals here have called a monster meeting for Sunday next. It will be held at the El Dorado music hall and numbers of the leading speakers among the Italian Colony will address the meeting to protest against the policy of the Government.

div.head: CAIRO'S THREATENED CAB STRIKE.
To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: sir,-I have seldom heard anything more absurd than the proposal of the Cairo cab drivers to go on strike if the project of putting 400 motor cabs in circulation on the Cairo streets is not vetoed by the Government. As far as can be seen at present, the general public and tourists especially would welcome the innovation. I have no hesitation in saying that the reckless way in which the Cairo arbaghis drive, their insolent manners, and the conditions of their horses, is a disgrace to civilisation. The daily scenes of cruelty to horses and mules to be witnessed in the Cairo streets are perfectly heartrending. Tourists have repeatedly called my attention to this and, if I mistake not, a letter from a prominent American appeared in your valuable paper some few months ago, protesting against the barbous way in which the Cairo cabdrivers teeat their horses. I repeat that the general public, and our winter visitors, would welcome the appearance of an efficient service of motor cabs, and that these may appear on the scene as soon as possible is the sincere wish of
Yours truly,
Onlooker.
Cairo, October 15.

div.head: CAIRO TO HELOUAN.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,-May I point out that the outlay for the crying want of a road from Helouan to Cairo need not be so great, if the prisoners from Tourah Convict Prison were taken off their present labour in the quarries on the hills and put on to road making. The Prisons Administration makes, I believe, a good profit from the supply of convict labour at the quarries and it is said that the authorities are disinclined therefore to avail themselves of this very practical form of labour for works of public utility. Considering, however, that there is a very great need for this road and that all material necessary for the metalling on this road is at hand, surely it would be more economical for the Government, in view of the high price of labour, to forego the profit from the quarry work and employ the men on the road.
Trouly Yours.
Motorist.
Cairo, October 16th.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman liner "Fabian" sailed for Liverpool direct yesterday at daybreak, with a general cargo including 3,478 bales cotton.
The Moss liner "Rameses" sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is due here on Monday morning, next, 21st inst. with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: SULTAN'S BIRTHDAY ANNIVERSARY.
div.p: On the eve of the 24th September, the Sultan's Anniversary, the usual illuminations and festive demonstrations were made, especially by the Moslem section, and early next morning the official reception was held at the Seraglio, The Governor General, Khalil Pasha, being absent in the Lebanon for reasons of health, Ismet Pasha, the military commandant, acted for him and presided over the reception, while Rear-Admired Faiek Pasha acted for Ismet Pasha at the official reception at the Barracks. At 9 a.m. the civil and military officials, and the spiritual heads called to tender their congratulations, and at 10 a.m. followed the Consular Corps, the Directors of the different administrations, and the notables of the town. Although the electric tramway started several weeks ago the construction of its line yet in honour of the Imperial fete, and by way of good augury, a ceremony was held at 11 a.m. to inaugurate the laying of the first rail of the line destined to start from a point between the Seraglio and the Dragoon's Station. In accordance with the traditional custom the ceremony began with a supplicatory prayer by the Mufti for the preservation of his Majesty's life. Soon after a few workmen that were at hand set to laying the inaugural rail, which has since been buried in dust through the ceaseless traffic. Among the large attendance the following personages were prominent:- Monsieur Jamolet, Direct of the Electric Tramway Co., Mr. George Covillom, Director of the Gas Company, Monsieur William Bourgain, Director of the Freneh Railway Co., Mr. Tremblay, sub-Director of the said Company. and Mr. Alfred Loir, Director of the Tombac Society.
Owing to the Vali's indisposition of the traditional immolation of sheep and the customary speechmaking were suppressed.

div.head: An Unfortunate Incident.
div.p: On the 28th ultimo a rather unpleasant incident occured to the Khedivial Mail Agency's chief clerk and right hand man of the agent, Mr. Chuchri Abou Chaar. The Khedivial steamer from Constantinople having arrived rather late Mr. Aboa Chaar solicited from the Sanitary Office the permission to pratique her that same evening for urgent reasons. As mail boats have the exceptional privilege of half an hour's grace after sunset the sanitary official accorded the permission provided there should be no objection on the part of the Passport Department for night communication. For some reason or other Mr. Abou Chaar did not meet with a ready response and during a hot discussion that ensued between him and Khaled Effendi, the commissaire de police of the quay, the latter forgot himself so far as to slap his interlocutor. Fortunately Khaled Effendi was not long in discovering his mistake, and he shortly after made amends to Mr. Abou Chaar. It is not known whether in the meantime the Khedivial Company has taken any official steps to enforce greater respect towards its representatives and maintain its prestige. It is considered however that the generous expression of regret spontaneously made by Khaled Effendi, who as a rule has avery affable demeanour, closes this incident.

div.head: the Hedjaz Railway.
div.p: By the Khedivial steamer "Assouan" arrived from Constantinople 38 officers of the Ottoman Navy destined for the employment, by imperial order, on the Hedjaz Railway. These officers left the same day for Haifta to take up their appointments.

div.head: Riot in Harbour.
div.p: On the 4th instant at about 7 o'clock in the morning a riotous altercation that threatened at one time to have very serious consequences, took place on board the Russia steamer "Rossia" from Port Said. As this vessel was steaming in and before dropping anchor in the outer harbour, a host of boatmen tried to board her and hustle off, as is their wont, both passengers and luggage. Captain Vergyanofsky, not liking this rather impudent and lawless manner in which this truculent band tried to invade his ship, ordered his officers and crew to repulse them by force of arms. Emboldened by the laxity of the Captaincy of the port, especially during the late regime, the boatmen of Beyrout have acquired a certain authoritative impudence which made them imagine themselves to be above the law, and in this instance they certainly were not going to submit to the orders of the subaltern officers and the crew of the "Russian" steamer, for in the eyes of these ignorant people Russia after her defeat in the Far East has lost every vestige of her old prestige in the East. But opposition to Russia dogged will and tenacity was sure to result in a fierce dispute. While the crew hurled the boatmen bodily, some down the gangway, and others clean overboard, the latter offered a determined resistance, plying both daggers and revolvers. For a moment the situation assumed an alarming gravity and the passengers were seized with panic, but fortunately the officers and crew finally rid the ship of its assailants, not however till after one of the officers had been badly scratched in the neck and one of the crew wounded by the revolver shot. On the side of boatmen one was wounded in the chest and another in the thigh. The incident has been reported by Mr. Valaditer, the agent of the Russian Navigation Company, to the Russian Consulate General, and Prince Gagature will no doubt be taking the matter up very energetically with the embassy at Constantinople using that the principle of the violation of Russian territory is hereby involved. Meantime the new Captain of the Port, Osman Bey, in whom high hopes of reform are laid, is said to have had some of the offending boatmen flagged and others fined.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lord Cromer's brother-in-law, Sir Hugh Shaw Stewart, of Ardgowan, who is one of the richest of the Scottish territorial magnates, is as keen a free-trader as Lord Cromer and has lately aroused some interest in political circles in England by declaring that be will not support a Unionist candidate for Greenock if the said candidate be a follower of the Tariff Reform policy.

Sir Vincent Corbett, the late Financial Adviser, left Cairo on his way to England on Wednesday evening. Among those who were at the station to bid him good-bye were Sir Eldon Gorst, the Ministers and the Adviserrs, the Sirdar, Lord Edward Cecil, the Governor of Cairo, the Commandant of the Cairo Police, Masaulay Bey and a large number of notables ad high functionatries.
Mrs. Harold Gorst, sister-in-law of Sir Eldon Gorst, contributed an interesting article to the "Daily Mail: last week, entitled "How women can made their husbands succeed."
Mr. Charles J. Nicole, Danish Vice-Consil, has returned to Cairo from his holiday.
Mrs. Bernard, the wife of the Director Finance, Sudan Government, has arrived in Cairo from Europe.

The death took place recently in Cairo of Mr. James Masson, an American millionaire and retired banker of Mobile, Alamda. Mr. Masson had for several seasons been a regular visitor to Cairo and Upper Egypt.

Lieut. Grant, the grandson of President Grant, who has become engaged to the only daughter of the U.S. Secretary of State has had an interesting and varied officer. While he was a boy his father was American Minister at the Austrian Court, and young Grant began his studies in the imperial military political in Vienna where he was a schooltutor of the present Khedive of Egypt.
Mr. P.H. East has been appointed as provisional engineer to the Assouan reservoir.
Mr. Donald Maclay has been appointed to the Assouan reservoirs, as provisional inspector of masonry.
Mr. Arthur Percy left London for Cairo on the 14th inst. to resume his duties at Shepheards for the 13th. year.

Among the visitors now staying at the Carlton Hotel, Ramleh, are the following:- Major and Mrs. A. F. Pilson, Capt. and Mrs. H. Swift, Rev. E. H. Blyth, Mr. J. Hickey, Miss K. Hickey, Mr. M. Goor, Mr. S. Claudius Bey, Mr. E. A. Powell, Mr. and Mrs. C. Gilbart Smith, Mr. and Mrs. J. Ricard, Miss Ricard, Miss D. Berry, Dr. and Mrs. Cullen Brown, Miss. L. E. McPhillips, Mr. and Mrs. A. H. Payton, Mr. and Mrs. N. Economo and family.
The following are expected in a few days at the Carlton Hotel, Dr. Adamidi and family, Mr. and Mrs. G. Ellerington Buckley, Major R. C. Pierce and family.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB.
div.p: To-morrow afternoon will take place at Gabbary at 3.30 p.m. the 60 yards juniors' and 110 yards seniors' championships. For the former championship there is no cup, the same having been won outright by C.E.L. Randall last season. For the latter Mr. H.P. Kingham's silver challenge cup will be swum for. In the event of there being sufficient entries three prizes will be presented by the club for each championship. The meeting will also include a polo match and team race versus King's Royal Rifles, diving exhibitions by juniors and seniors, etc., etc. Members alight at the dock tramway halt. Ladies are specially invited to attend.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Aujourd'hui a midi)
div.p: Loaverture de notre marché a été ce matin pire qu'bier. Les ordres de ventes afflasient en aussi grand nombre et les transactions in- fimes et olairsemées, qui ont en. lieu, ont coaté aux vendeurs Toi concessions. Vers la fin, poartant, un raffermissément s'est prodoit avec une amélioration dans la ten- dance. On n'en a pas moins clétaré 4 un nivead généralement inférieur a celui d'bier.

Le Caire continue 4 nous inonder de paquets de titres. Ce serait les banques de reports naguére aux prises avec de graves diffcultés q3i profiteraient surtout de la reprise actuelle pour liquider une partie de leurs comptes. 8i Yon ajoute & cela la mauvaise impression produite par les ventas presque quotidiennes aux enchéres, les. réalisations de profits et la cessation des achats da Stock Exchange en valears égyptiennes, |ui-mé@me influencé par la mauvaise tenue des bourses Américair.es, on voit que les motifs ne manquent pas 4 la dépreasion actuelle. Comme pour combler la mesure, voici que le taox privé d'escompte, aprés étre longtemps resté aux environs de 4%, hausse & 4 3/8 %.
Il a été vend ce matin aux enchéres pubbhi- ques 200 Lunghis a 1/4 et 250 a 15/64, 100 Agricole a 8 15/64, 150' United a 1/4, et 150 Karam (industrial and Building) a 21/64.
Parmi les titres les plus traités il faut citer Agricole, la Cassa di Soonto, les Ritz Hotels, la Delta Land, et dans de moindres proportions le Comptoir, les Natigovich Hotels et la Béhéra.

L' Agricole de 8 9/82 4 8 7/32, la National Bank d¢ 21 7/8 a 21 13/16, la Daira de 18 11/16 4 13 5/8, la Béhéra de 24 a 23 7/8, la privilégiée Khedivial Mail de 4 3/16 a 41/8, la Land Bank de 7 5/1647 1/4, l'Union Poncitre de 413/16 & 43/4, et le Crédit Pranco-Egyptien de 4 3/16 4 4 1/8.
Les Lots Turcs progreasent, au contraire, de 160 & 161, les Nungovich Hotels de 16 3/8 a 16 3/4 et la Banque d'Orient de 119 1/2 a 120.
Quant a l'Obligation Crédit Poncier, l'an- cienne fiéchit de 297 & 296, tandis que la non- velle reprend de 2624 254.

En titres d'ordre secondaire, la Salt & Soda recule de 18/- a 17/9, In Cassa di Sconto de 50 A 48, les Estates de 19/82 a 9/16, le Comp- toir de 215/16 l'ancienne et 3 la nouvelle a 27/8 et 215/16 respectivement, la Building Lands de 2 1/16 a 2 1/32, action Allotment de 2 3/8 A 2 1/8, la Levant de 9/16 & 1/2, In fondateur United de 1 4 7/8, |'Helouan de 3/16 & 7/32, la Levico de 1/2 & 7/16 l'action et de 4& 3 1/4 la fondateor. En avance il n'y a que l'Ordinary: Khedivial Mail de 22 4 22/3, et la fondatenr Comptoir de 2 4 2 1/16.

Il n'est guére possible de dire quelle sera lorientation de la semaine prochaine. Mais ai la baisse continue pour les bonnes valeurs, l'exots de leur dépréciation méme sera |'origine | Wane nouvelle reprise. Pour oe de pure spéculation, nous l'avons déja dit, le mieux pour les non-professionnels est de s'abstenir.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES BY CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres est renseigne en hausse de 1/8 a 4 1/4 pour cent.

Au Stock-Exchange, le Consolide anglais est reste invarie a 82 5/8. L'Unifiee a hausse de 1/4 a 103. La National Bank a ete soutenue a 22 1/8, la Daira 13 7/8, la Delta Lighta a 10 1/2 et l'Agricole a 8 1/2.
A Paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptien a gagne 3 francs a 698. La Banque d'Athenes est restee inchangee a 111. Les Lots Turcs se sont assure 1 franc a 168.
Ici, la seance a ete aussi nulle que celle d'hier, avec cette difference que le recul des grosses valeurs a'est arrete randisque lespetites out porte tout le poids de la mauvaise tendance du marche.

Les tassements sans etre tres importants sont cependant significatifs, les affairs ayant ete tres limitees et les vendeurs faisant defaut aux cours actuels pour de nombreux titres, ce qui tendrait a prouver que nous approchons de la limite extreme de la baisse.
Au demeurant, cet etat transitoire peut encore durer quelques temps vu les vesoins monetaires pressants a cet epoque, mais ce ne saurait etre, a tous egards, de bien longue duree.
Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National Bank se releve a 21 7/8-15/16. La Cassa di Sconto recule a 51 et la fondateur Societe Generale a 40.

La Delta Light est legerement atteinte a 10 1/4. Le Credit Foncier Egyptien s'inscrit en recul a 696, son obligation ancienne a 299 et la nouvelle a 252. La Behera hausse encore a 23 3/4-7/8. La Wardan Estate est cotee 4 (nominal) et la fondateur 5 (nominal). L'Allotment flechit a 2 1/16-1/8 et sa part a P.T. 58. La Societe d'Entreprises et Travaux est ramenee a 2 et la fondateur a P.T. 42.

Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Egyptian Hotels (Baehler) sont moins soutenus a 6 3/16. L'Upper Egypt remonte a 3 alors que les National Hotels retombent a 2 5/16-3/8. Les Excelsior Hotels gagnent 1/4 a 2 1/4.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land tombe a 1 1/2. La New Egyptian progresse a 13/3. La Land Investment and Building est realisee a 0 1/4 est sa part a 0 3/4. Les Egyptian Constructions sont plus faibles a 0 5/6 de meme que les Hooker a 0 5/16-3/8 et les Lunghis a 0 1/4. Seules les Ordinary Khedivial Mail sont en hausse a 22/6 sur le bruit d'un dividende plus eleve.
Nous detachons de notre correspondance de Londres, en date 11 Octobre, les passages suivants:

"Nous avons depuis quelque temps un marche indecis, haussant ou baissant aux moindres indices favorable ou defavorables en Amerique. Les affaires sont calmes et l'on ne prevoit pas de forte reprise pour un avenir tres proche, car on se ressent encore de la chute du cuivre et des liquidations qui en ont suivi.
"Neanmoins dans les milieux financiers on a bon espoir, car la situation automnale se presente mieux que l'annee derniere et l'argent se cantonee a un prix qui n'est point trop eleve pour l'epoque.
"Nos Consolides restent soutenus ou avec des varitions insignifiantes. Le seul point noir a l'horizon est la baisse en perspective des valeurs de chemins de fer.
"Les fonds d'Etats etrangers et les chemins americains sont eu meilleure posture, a la suite des derniers dividendes declares et de quelques achats assez suivis.

"Le marché des valeurs égyptiennes a "té en général ferme cette semaine avec pea d af- faires cependant, sauf sur les banques et la Daira qui ont eu une certaine animation. L'A- gricole est restée toute la semaine dans les en- virons de 8 1/2, mais cet aprés-midi le cours s'est raffermi 4 8 19/3?. La National a donné lien 4 un bon nombre de transactions, étant trés demande ea cléture anjourd'hui 4 22 3/8. La Daira en forte demande a repris de 13 1/2 & 13 15/16, Les Markets ont donné lieu aquel- ques affaires & 28/9 A la suite de la déolaration d'an dividende semestriel de 3 1/2 % contre 3 % l'an dernier. Il y avait achetears de Salt and Soda aux environs de 19/-. Les petites va- leurs sont délaissées."
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

M.M. les actionnaires de la "Societe H. de Vries and Boutigny Ltd." sont avises que le solde du sur leurs actions est payable au plus tard le 24 Octobre courant plus les interets de retard calcules au taux de 9% l'an.
Faute par eux d'effectuer le dit paiement dans le delai fixe, il leur sera fait application des art. 20 et 21 des Statuts dont la teneur est la suivante:

Art. 20. If any Member fail to pay any call or instalment on or before the day appointed for the payment of the same, the Directors may at any time thereafter, doring soch time as the call or instalment remains unpaid, serve a notice on such Member requiring him to pay the same, together with any interest that may have accrued and all expenses that may have been incurred by the Company by reason of such non-payment.

Art. 21. The notice shall name a day (not being less than fourteen days from the (ate of the notice) and a place or places onand at which such cal] or instalment and such inter- est and expenses as aforesaid are to be paid. The notice shall also state that in the event of non-payment at or before the time and at the place appointed, the shares in respect of which' the call was made or instalment is payable wil! be liable to be forfeited.

— MM. les actionnaires du '' Comptoir Financier et Commercial d'Egypte " sont con- voqués en Assemblée Générale Ordinaire an nuelle pour le jeudi 31 Octobre 1907 a 4 h. 1/2 p.m. ad siége de la Société a Alexandrie.

A Yordre du jour: Rapports du Conseil d' Administration et des Censears. Approbation des comptes. Nomination des Censeurs et fixa- tion de leur indemnité pour l'exercice 1907 1908. Nomination d'un administrateur. Fixa- tion dela date du paiement de l'intérét dQ a la 3éme émission.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report
div.p: We have again to report a quiet market in Egyptian, the only change in quotations being 1/16 per lb advance in brown, whilst Uppers are unchanged.
In Futures only a limited business has been done, and following are the latest quotations:-

American Futures.The Market this week has been dull and featureless, with constant fluctuations of a few points either way. There has been less pressure to sell generally and to-days closing values are 7 1/2 to 1 points higher than those of last Thursday, the near positions having appreciated whilst the more distant positions have fallen to discounts. The Market having been too much depressed upon the Ginners and Bureau reports reached sharply, bur failed to maintain more than a partial improvement. We are now coming to the period when there will be considerable nervousness, a sudden fall in temperature, would with the considerable shortage existing in all the markets especially in New York and New Orleans, probably cause a sharp rise, but so far the article has failed to attract any important outside interest, due no doubt largely to the stringency of money, and the depressed condition of Stocks and Shares.

div.head:
THE RAILWAY CRISIS.
BELL ADVOCATES STRIKE.

div.p: Mr. Bell, addressing the railwaymen here, said that if the Companies persisted in refusing a conference the ballot would show that an enormous majority were in favour of a strike. The meeting passed a resolution that the only course open to the men was to strike.
(Reuter)

div.head:
U.S.A. AND THE PHILIPPINES.
SELF GOVERNMENT QUESTION.

div.p: Mr. Taft, opening the Assembly, said that he did not believe that the Philippines were fitted for self-government for at least a generation, but that the matter was entirely in the hands of Congress. He was confident that they recognised the necessity for supporting the American Government.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE SHREWSBURY DISASTER.
BOARD OF TRADE ENQUIRY.

div.p: Mr. Lloyd George personally publicly opened the Board of Trade enquiry regarding the Shrewsbury disaster. He examined the witnesses himself, which was an unprecedented proceeding. The signalmen stated that two sets of signals were against the train. The guard deposed that it was travelling at between 50 and 60 miles an hour. The brakes were ineffectually applied.

Mr. Lloyd George, speaking at Manchester, said that the Board of Trade would not spare their efforts to scrutinise to the fullest the great mystery attending the Shrewsbury disaster in view of the similarity of recent accidents in which competent drivers rushed ahead madly in the face of signals on clear nights.
(Reuter)

M. Pichon has communicated M. Regnault's despatches concerning his conversations with Abd-el-Aziz. As far as French interests are concerned, Abd-el-Aziz has taken measure to send a mehalla strong enough to reduce the hostile tribes.
(Havas)
The Ministry denies the recall of Colonel Santa Olalla.
(Havas)

div.head:
THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
COURT OF ARBITRATION.

div.p: The plenary Conference has adopted by 38 votes, six minor states abstaining, the British resolution recommending the Powers to adopt a permanent Court of Arbitration. It is hoped that the final sitting will take place to-morrow.
(Reuter)

div.head:
EXPEDITION TO FLORES.
FIGHT WITH THE REBELS.

div.p: The Dutch expedition to Flores is meeting with serious resistance. 198 rebels were killed in a recent engagement, after which many chiefs surrendered.
(Reuter)
M. Caillaux exposed to the Council of Ministers the financial situation, which is satisfactory. The year shows a credit balance.
(Havas)

div.head:
AMERICA AND JAPAN.
NAVAL VISIT TO PACIFIC.
AN ALARMIST ARTICLE.

div.p: The anti-Governmental newspaper "Sun" in an alrmist article states that the chief reason for sending the squadron to the Pacific is to prepare for a war with Japan.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE KERMAN RISING.
THE RIOTERS REPULSED.

div.p: The Governor of Kerman telegraphs that he has repulsed the townspeople attacking him.
(Reuter)

div.head:
FLOODS IN SPAIN.
KING'S ACTIVE SYMPATHY.

div.p: The King is visiting the flood swept districts around Malaga.
(Reuter)

An official note says that the fears of insufficiency of funds in establishments issuing bank notes are groundless. All have ample margins and the Government would not hesitate to assume all responsibities if occasion arose
(Reuter)

div.head:
AMERICA TO ENGLAND.
WIRELESS SERVICE OPENED.

div.p: Signor Marconi announced this morning that the wireless service from America to England had been opened. Two evening newspapers here publish short telegrams from America headed "Wireless."
(Reuter)

div.head:
SUEZ CANAL COMPANY.
SIR W GARSTIN APPOINTED DIRECTOR.

div.p: Sir William Garstin has been nominated a Director of the Suez Canal in succession to the late Major-General Sir J. Ardagh.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE ABYSSINIAN MISSION.
RECEPTION AT ATHENS.

div.p: The members of the Abussinian mission have been received in audience by the Crown Prince, to whom they handed a letter from Menelik and the Chain of the Order of the Elephant for the King and also gifts.
(Reuter)
There were 82 cases of cholera here yesterday 13 of which have proved fatal.
(Reuter)
The Emperor's condition continues favourable.
(Havas)
Wheat yesterday reached 40/ a quarter in several provincial markets.
(Reuter)
It is believed that M. Isvolsky's business here is to pave the way for a new loan.
(Reuter)
The resumption of work is almost complete,
(Havas)
The Government intends prosecuting the railwaymen in Turin who lately joined the general strike thus violating the recent law.
(Reuter)
Torrential rains continue to fall in central and southern France.
(Reuter)

div.head: NEILL'S LATEST ESTIMATE.
div.p: In their monthly report on the cottou crop, Messrs. Neill Brothers state that the receipts for the four weeks ended 4th instant amounted to 964,000 bales, as against 1,208,000 bales at. the corresponding period last year, making the total brought to light since Ist September last 1,054,000 bales, against 1,320,000 bales. The exports for the four weeks were 449,000 bales, against 581,000 bales, making the total since Ist September 477,000 bales, against 581,000 bales. American spinners since the date mentioned have taken 328,000 bales, compared with 329,000 bales. Com menting on these figures, Messrs. Neill Brothers state that one month of the new season has now passed without any statistical develop- ments which can be relied upon as any guide. According to the official figures supplied by the New Orleans' Cotton Exchange, 841,000 bales were brought to light during September, against 995,000 last year and 1,815,000 in September, 1905, while Messrs. Neill's own returns up to 4th October sum ap 1,054,000 bales against 1,264,000 and 1,582,000 in the past two years. A noteworthy featare is that the port receipts from the Gulf up to date are much smaller than last year (namely, 306,000, against 630,000), while those at the Atlantic ports are in excess, say, 428,000, against 356,00. The present total of port receipts was attained only five daysearlier in 1906 and nine days earlier in 1905, so there is nothing surprising in the deficiency up to date for 9 crop so late as this was reported to be; but it is surprising that the past week should only have given a total brought to light of 307,000, against 298,000 last week, instead of showing the rapid expansion natural to this time of year. The explanation of this is no doubt to be found in the holding back now being practised both by farmers, who are in no hurry to sell, on the one hand, and by spinners, who do not need to buy, on the other. When either the one or the other party changes its policy, the movement will doubtless resume a more normal course.

div.head: EXPORTS AND VISIBLE SUPPLY.
div.p: The c.i.f. business between England and America has been unusually slow until the past week, and up to the present only 203,000 bales have sailed for Great Britain, against 220,000 last year and 272,000 in 1905. During the same period the shipments to the Conti- nent have been 274,000 bales, against 361,000 last year, and the American spinners have taken a good average supply. The visible sapply of American cotton is now distributed as follows:—

row.cell: Visible supply at and afloat for Great Britain

div.p: As regards the invisible supply——that is, the stocks of American cotton held by spinners - -it has been shown how they probably stood at the opening of the season on the basis of Messrs. Neill's estimated consumption ot 12,750,000 bales. Messrs. Neill still think that that 12,750,000 was as fair an estimate as could be taken. The International Spinners' Census have lately issued a docament which has led the unwary into sundry statistical pitfalls, the chief of which is that the consumption of 1906-7 was only 11,669,000 bales of American cotton! Bunt this is because the returns are only from 100,521,000 spindles ont of .the 114,096,000 actually at work. To get a rough idea of what. woold have resulted from a complete return, Messrs. Neill set down the census figures for Europe as follows, all in 1,000' (American cotton only) :—

The above calculation of 3,451,000 as the British consomption indivated by the census is probably too large, as many of the unreported spindles are no doubt working upon Egyptian cotton, and here are nommieans at hand of dif. ferentiating them. Messrs. Neill therefore feel that it is unnecetsary to change their estimate of 3,300,000 bales for Great Britain. Their Continental and other figures are quite strik- ingly confirmed, and they think 12,750,000 for the total consumption still successfully holds the field.

div.head: MILL STOCKS.
div.p: As to mill stocks, the spinners' census show- ed a total on/8ist August, 1907, of 2,078,000. This included for America and-Japan 1,054,000, leaving for Burope 1,019,000 on 72,860,000 spindles. This upon the fall number(86,271,000) would indicate European mill stocks of Ameri- | can cotton on 8lst August 1,214,000, com- pared with the estimate of 10th September, 1,185,000, a net variation of only 29,000 bales. The current ideas of mill stocks in America have been thrown into confusion by a recent publication from the Census Bureau, and mail details must be awaited before going further into that part of the subject. Mr. Hester estimates the Northern mill stocks at 376,000 bales (Messra. Neill made them 389,000).

div.head: CROP CONDITIONS.
div.p: As to the crop, the trade has been suffering from the hot and cold fits which must be its lot in these days when redundant official re- ports sncceed each other at intervals so frequent as to leave no time for consideration betw the effect of one and the anticipation of next. If these reports were trustworthy, the unsettlement they cause would be excasable, but influenced as they are believed to be by pecuniary, speculative and even political consi- derations, they have become more of a nuisance than benefit. For the present season, Messrs. | Neill have decided upon the following ax 0 reasonable estimate of the acreage :—
The Egyptian Prince ia arousing huge interest in America. The "Philadelphia Public Ledger," of the 6th ult. says :—

Full of enthusiasm for Philadelphia, Prince Pagratide of Egypt spent yesterday sightseeing. His nervous vitality, inherited from his Bedouin ancestors, seemed to steel him against fatigne, and he saw more in one day than most Phila- delphians see in a year.

Small of stature, with mobile features and the wide dark eyes, he is the true type of Egyp- tian. His education in London and Paris enables him to speak French and English with equal fluency, and his immaculate clothes held no suggestion af the East; they were of the West, western.

"I am amused," the Prince said, "to find that the interest of those I meet lies in my opinion of your American women. They are indeed well worth speaking of. Never have I seen so many types, each so perfect in its way.

But I have said all this before. I am full of admiration, too, for your great department stores. They would be impossible in my land, where each merchant distrusts all others, but I can readily see their convenience."

div.head: STUDENT OF SOCIOLOGY.
div.p: The Prince has travelled iri America before and has béen South and West in his visits. He is a close friend of Henry Clews, the banker, with whom he spent several weeks in Newport before coming to this city, and who was his host ata luncheon at the Lawyers' Club in New York and also at the Stock Exchange. The Prince is a student of sociology, politics: and economies, and he admires without reserve the democratic condition in the United States.

"In my country," he said sadly, "we have no independence and we grow more and more under the domination of the English. Yet it is truly the most wonderfnl country in the world. Unless you have been to Egypt-yon cannot understand the fascination of the whole conn- try and of the desert. "The Garden of ANah," I think one'of your writers calls it. The Arabs are a strange race. They are slow to anger but quick to strike if injured. It is difficult to know what fires burn ander their quiet exterior, but, so far as I know, the reli- gious difficulties we are now having have not roused any lasting tronble among the rage as a whole."

div.head: LEAVES FOR ATLANTIC CITY.
div.p: The Prince left last night for Atlantic City. "I hear it is a very gay place," he said with a smile. "And while I have seen many places so called 1 am anxious to see one typically Ame- rican. From there | shall go to Texas to stady the growth and treatment of cotton. In Egypt. I have great cotton plantations and | am there- fore interested in the indastry. It is really for that that | am here, and not, believe me, for a rich wife. How could one choose anyway among 80 many charming women?"

The Prince was graduated from Eton and is a close triend of Prince Ali, the brother of the Khedive, who is popular in London. He traces his ancestry back to the year 800 A.D., his father and thers having been Prime Ministers ot Egypt.

div.head: WHEN GREEK MEETS GREEK.
ASSAULT BY A JUDGE'S SON.
div.p: At Bow-street Police-court, last week, Achilles | Sapountzakis, a student, living in Milman. street, W.C., wascharged, before Mr. Marsham, with assaulting Even Keloo Nicholas Taranas, a cigarette dealer. The proseoator and the prisoner are Greeks, and the evidence had to be interpreted. It was stated that the prose- cutor called upon the prisoner at his lodgings, at an early hodr in the morning, to collect an account owing for cigarettes. He was shown into the prisoner's bedroom, and asked for his money. According to the case for the pro- secution the prisoner jumped out of bed, and struck the prosecutor a severe blow on the eye with a clothes brush.

Mr. Curtis Bennett, who appeared for the defence, asked the prosecutor if he knew that the prisoner's father was a Lord Justice of Appeal in Athens.—The prosecutor (through the interpreter). I have heard that his father is a judge, but I don't: know whether he is a big one ora little one (laughter).—Mr. Cartis Bennett : Is he referring to size or reputation! —Other evidence having been given, Mr. Curtis Bennett said it was a fact that the prisoner's father was a Judge of Appeal in Athens. He had sent his son to London to learn the English language. When the pro- secutor cx'led for his account the prisoner had no money to pay him with, as his allowance had not arrived. The prosecutor was insistent, and the pri oner, who had been suffering from neuralgia, thought he was going to strike him. He therefore took the initiative and struck the prosecutor with his fist, not with a braush.— Prisoner was ordered to pay £3 and £1 16s. costs.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: The following telegram has been received at Khartoum by El-Miralai Matchett Bey from the Sirdar and Governor General :

"On my return from leave of absence and on taking over military and civil command | desire you will accept and express to all under your command my appreciation of the good services rendered during the trying summer months.
I deeply regret the casualties amongst Bri tish, Egyptian and Sndanese Officers, Officials and men.

I am very sensible of the great inconvenience caused to both official and private individuals especially the trading communities by the abnormal. rains which have so seriously inter- fered with railway traffic, but am rejoiced to hear that all repairs have been most satisfac torily completed.
As I shall remain in Cairo for some weeks in connection with budget matters I desire you to convey to all my hearty greetings on my return."

div.head: AVOID A BREAKDOWN.
DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS' EFFICACY.
div.p: In reality there are two particular forces in all our organs—one which is always in opera- tion, the other which is held in reserve for extraordinary purposes only. It is exdess in any habit that calls into action the force in reserve ; butas strength is only regained by a | long and difficult process, it follows that it is unwise to tax the organism to its fullest extent too often, especially inthe case of elderly people. | If one makes a demand on one's reserve of strength, fatigue results.

There is one means by which fatigue may be | avoided, and that is Dr. Williams' Pink Pills | for Pale People, which should he taken As s00n as one feelsa little run down. They will be found an anfailing source of strength. In order to demonstrate the validity of thie claim for Dr. Williams' Pink Pills, the following case, taken from thousands similar, may be cited:-
M. Simandae, curé of Percey, near Flogny (Yonne), writes:-

"In consequence of overwork and exhaustion, my niece, Mlle. Marie Anne Brocard, fell into an acute state of amnesia. Her cheeks were pale and her lips white, and for a long time, she experienced palpitation, buzzing sounds in the head, loss of appetite, and lack of sleep. At length my niece took Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People. After the second box she was considerably better, and her improvement was maintained until she was able to resume, her occupation without fatigue. Her appetite has returned, her-head is clear, and she has an excellent complexion."
Dr. Williams' Pink Pills are a sovereign cure for anemia, chlorosis, neurasthenia, general weakness, stomach troubles, sick headaches, rheumatic pains, and constitutional irregulari- ties.

div.head: SUDAN IRRIGATION SERVICE.
NOTICE
div.p: Applications (in writing only) for places as clerks in the Sudan Branch of the Egyptian Irrigation Service will be received at the Ministry of Public Works up to the 25th October by the Inspector General of Irrigation for the Sudan.
Some educational qualifications and a good knowledge of English is essential. Pay L.E. 8 to L.E. 15 per month according to qualifications.

Applications should state qualifications and experience and give references and should be accompanied by copies of certificates; and should be addressed to the Inspector General of Irrigation for the Sudan, Public Works Ministry, Cairo, in envelopes labelled "Application for post of clerk."

div.p: The Shareholders of the Egyptian Salt & Soda Company Limited are informed that, by decision of the Board an interin dividend of 39 milleiemes per share being 4 per cent, will be payable on and after November 1st 1907 at the Offices of the National Bank of Egypt at Cairo, Alexandria and London on presentation of Coupon No 7.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
AVIS
div.p: L'adjudication pour la fourniture de 400 grilles pour puisards et de 200 regards de visite a ete revoyee jusqu'au 5 Novembreprochain.
Le cautionnement est fixe a L.Eg. 75.
Le cahier des charges est depose au bureau Technique ou il peut etre consulte par les interesses tous les jours de 9h. a midi, les jours teries exceptes.
Les offres devront etre adresses sous pli cachete a Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalite avant le 5 Novembre 1907.
Elles pourront egalement etre deposees en seance de la Delegation le meme jour a 5h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission" pour fourniture grilles et puisards".

Le cautionnement ou le recu d'une banque, d'apres les conditions du cahier des charges, devra etre remis separement au Service de la Comptabilite general avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 5 Novembre 1907a midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci=dessus sera ecartee.
Alexandrie le 14/10/07.

31104-3-3(signe) Dr Schiess.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette. "
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For further information apply to the Company's Offices at Cairo, Alexandria, Tantah, Zagazig, Damanhour or Saida Zenab
